女主，幼年时期的女队长
教授

女队长为什么成了龙骑兵队长，她那有点神经病的个性是怎么来的？
领主的生意是怎么搞起来的
教授的早期研究
前作中有才华的魔法理论专业女助理为什么选择了做心理学医生

最最关键的是

围绕魔法，以及魔法来源的那个神秘的魔法药剂背后的政治，经济，社会因素


上一次的作品讨论的是围绕魔法的社会宏观因素
为什么会通过那个法案“剥夺”了普通人购买魔药的能力，这背后的社会因素，经济因素，海外殖民策略等等
本座讨论的范围比较小，但是背后牵扯出了一系列的问题
比如为何人造药水是要被禁止的——这背后深刻的政治社会经济因素，甚至牵扯到国际形势
比如是什么促使领主去思考控制药水的法案问题
影响魔法的因素到底是什么


甚至于一个相当大的伏笔——领主的儿子到底怎么来的
难道是领主和本作中她的孩子？那为什么后作中她没有出现呢？这中间发生了什么

还是有太多的问题没有解决


玩游戏很多年了，各种架空类的世界观见过不少，但是本作这样小制作还能反映出深刻世界观的就很少见了

尤其是不管是前作还是本作，很多问题的讨论并不是简单的摆个问题然后用中二思维来解释一遍
游戏中人物的很多讨论是比较有深度的，我相信有一定文化基础的人应该能感觉出来
比如本作中对于什么是精神病人这个概念的讨论
很深入，很具体，而且相对比较专业
院长用的是统计理论，试图用密度分布中的两侧尖端来说明既然一侧尖端不被认为有病，那么凭什么给另一侧就要被认为有病，这不公平
然而后来的女医生用进化论反驳了这个观点：之所以人们偏向一侧的概率而不是另一侧概率，是因为这是自然进化的选择——那些偏向错误方向的物种恐怕都消失了，所以人类成了这个样子，因此对病人”原样保护“更有意义的是个人的“进化适应”
这样的思考很多，而且用语比较专业，让人不觉得违和感太强，这和某些中二类架空游戏是不一样的

作品最后，一切都完结了，大家通过讨论和回忆发现其实几个主要角色都有这样或那样的精神问题

那么问题来了：你是精神病吗？


本作的核心是，一个少女怎样从无到有获得了魔法，而重新融入了社会

社会在工业化大发展下，从小农经济的个体相对富足，演化到社会阶层极度分化大部分底层沦落为事实上的魔法贫困之后，女龙骑兵队长的所作所为，和她幼年时立下的志向还一样吗？她难道没有碰上她”精神父亲“前任队长的后尘？当年她要保护那些希望能带来低价药水的人们， 而在本作中她本人却成了追杀给人们带来低价药水的走私抵抗组织的龙骑兵队长，女队长被社会排斥，融入社会，成为上层精英，最终成为特权鹰犬的过程跃然纸上两部作品遥相呼应，精神上融为一体

35164447.review:
The game is not bad, but I also would not consider it good.

While the concept of its magic system remains to be interesting, there is still much to be desired. As "meaningful" as the game's social commentaries were, just like its predecessor An Octave Higher, they feel unnecessary and ultimately detract from the various characters' emotional journey. The mental patients discussion is just as excessive as the Libertads were in the previous game. In my opinion, the game's magic system is much more suitable for exploring individual issues: in this world, one's emotional strength directly translates to his/her magic proficiency/output; how a person is feeling much directly affects his/her action as well as the progression of the story.

The game may have been better if it had focused on the interactions among the characters. Give us more interaction between Woolf and Janis, or between Janis and Candela, or (insert names of any other two characters). The supposed emotional moments of the game would have worked much better with just a little more emotional build-up.

In conclusion, playing the game was not a bad experience; it really was not a great/memorable experience either.

31896274.review:
One Small Fire at a Time is a visual novel that is the prequel to An Octave Higher.  Although it is helpful to have played An Octave Higher, as there are familiar characters in both VNs, it is not necessary to do so.  In One Small Fire at a Time, you play as Janis, a 13-year old girl who is considered "mad" because she has "magic deficiency disorder."  As you can guess, that means that Janis can't use magic, which is very unusual since in the world where Janis is, Overture, magic casters are the norm and anyone who can't cast magic is abnormal.  As Janis copes with the hardships of her illness (mainly dealing with bullying), she crosses paths one day with Aiden Woolf, a dragoon commander who comes to Eclipse, the madhouse where Janis is living, and he is there on a mission to investigate the owners of Eclipse.  Although Eclipse looks like the usual madhouse whose inmates include those like Janis and anyone whose behavior doesn't conform to what society expects of them, there is more behind the madhouse and it is Woolf's mission (from the king) to find out what it is.  I won't reveal anything more story-wise but I'll point out that One Small Fire at a Time does have branching paths so you can get the true ending and alternate endings.

Now to my thoughts on this VN.  ;)  I truly enjoyed An Octave Higher and I was very excited when this VN came out.  I had high expectations for it and I wasn't disappointed at all.  First, I love Janis as the main character.  For those familiar with An Octave Higher, Janis is a supporting character in it and in One Small Fire at a Time, we see Janis as she was before she became a dragoon commander and it was interesting to learn that she couldn't use magic.  I loved her personality and I couldn't help laughing at times at how she addressed others.  Also, the writing itself was great.  I found myself getting really involved in the story and although we do see events from Janis' point of view, we also see another side, as when Woolf, along with his companions Professor Poe and Joff Godwin, investigates what's going on at Eclipse and its owners.  The art style is like that in An Octave Higher and if you like it then, you'll like it here as well.  Also, I love the orchestral pieces that are played and I think they fit very well with the time period that the game takes place.  (Basically, think of the US slightly before the Industrial Period.)  

Overall, I truly enjoyed playing One Small Fire at a Time and getting to learn about Janis' story.  It was great to see familiar characters as well as new characters.  If you liked An Octave Higher, I believe you'll love this one, too.  Also, I'll note that for those who know what the true ending is in An Octave Higher, you may be able to take a good guess as to what the true ending is in here, too.  ;)  Congrats to the devs for making another wonderful VN and I hope we'll get to see another VN in the world of Overture in the future.  ^^

Another awesome VN from Kidalang! I liked it so much, I went through the first playthrough (5 hours) in one sitting; couldn't stop reading. I do admit that I liked An Octave Higher a bit more, but this prequel was definitely a close second. While some have suggested otherwise, I do think the VN is more enjoyable if you've read An Octave HIgher first. An Octave Higher explains the magical system and gives an overall introduction to the world in these stories. Besides, it's more interesting to see Janis's backstory while knowing who she is in An Octave Higher. 

Like in An Octave Higher, this story was very thought-provoking and causes the reader to consider things about life. It particularly raises questions about the treatment of those with mental illnesses in society. As someone who suffers from depression/anxiety, I did relate quite a bit to some of the rhetoric used in the story. 

Ideas on the time lapse: (kinda spoiler-ish)
Based on how young Janis is in this game and how old she looks in An Octave Higher, I suspected the time between the two is maybe about 10 years or so, but thinking about it, I've decided that can't be right. Joff (another character in An Octave Higher) hasn't married or had his son in this story, and since his son was a teenager in An Octave Higher, assuming he got married (maybe to [spoiler]Ena[/spoiler]) and his wife immediately got pregnant, then maybe the time between the stories is about 15 years. Perhaps a bit more. They might even state Joff's son's age at some point in An Octave Higher, but I can't recall since I played it quite a while ago. 

The joke ending was, once again, quite amusing.

I HIGHLY recommend this game (as well as An Octave Higher) to those who enjoy thought-provoking VNs.

26729681.review:
This game ticked all the boxes for me. Interesting and developed setting, good characters, a gripping story and nice art. I loved the short chapters which made it easy to follow - a recent spell of depression has done a number on my concentration span, so the short chapters and clear-cut scenes were really nice.

There are lots of interesting ideas explored here, particularly about mental health. I'm always a little wary when I see something set in an asylum (as in countless horror games), but the creators had some really good observations about the nature of madness.

The setting was another plus. How magic would affect society was portrayed fairly realistically, at least to my mind, and I always love to see fantasy worlds where magic is used as another form of technology or science, rather than the standard swords, dragons and wizards set-up.

Although there is a clear 'true end', there are a number of alternates. I really enjoyed seeing how the choices affected the story, for better or worse. I like that the 'true end' is not necessarily the happiest end for all the characters...

On to characters, another plus. Although it's short, I felt the characters were well-formed. I actually liked the protagonist, so kudos is due there as likeable protagonists seem to be few and far between. I found Aidan Woolf a little lacking though, which kind of throws a spanner in the works since he's a major character...I suppose the fact that he just explains his backstory maybe made him a little flat for me. My only other complaint was the propensity for death-bed scenes - a pet hate of mine.

All in all, I really enjoyed this visual novel. Do give it a read, it's well-worth it.

24946782.review:
Some things up front: 
1) This is a prequel to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/352780/] An Octave Higher[/url]. This game is playable as a standalone, but knowledge from the other will be helpful and will probably make it more enjoyable.
2) This is a visual novel. There are choices, but otherwise there is no gameplay.
3) Just like An Octave Higher, this has some mature themes. For example, sexual violence, mental illness, and suicide are discussed, sometimes at length.

The Good:
1) Excellent writing. It manages to be both funny and disturbing as the situation calls for it. The story moves at a quick pace without being rushed. 
2) The music is similar to (and partly the same as) An Octave Higher. I personally think this is a good thing. Classical music mixed with thematic music for kinds of scenes and situations.
3) Great art again, both backgrounds and characters. The styling is consistent so if you like the preview images, that is what you will get.
4) Thematically very interesting. Just like in An Octave Higher, characters tend to wax philosophical at appropriate times. They wrestle with tough questions, and the reader is invited to think about it too. This time, the focus is on the nature of mental illness.

The Not So Good:
1) Some of the humor was funny but took me out of the story. The references broke immersion in a couple spots. It turned out okay because I got back into it just fine, but that could annoy some people.
2) The ending is a bit jarring. Some of the characters' actions didn't feel quite right. No spoilers here, but be aware that you may not really click with the ending.
3) A bit short. I completed the full all routes in a litle over 4 hours. 

The Verdict:
I'd recommend giving this a read after An Octave Higher if you enjoyed that visual novel. I think An Octave Higher is a bit better (at least as a standalone game). If you liked An Octave Higher, I think you'll like this one too, especially if you find the discussion of mental illness compelling.

23512773.review:
Schönen guten Abend mein name Florian "aniFlo" F. ich werde die 

Ich habe heute die Ehre euch eine Review zu One Small fire At A Time zu schreiben
und die Frage zu beantworten sind es kleine schritte bis zu einer Großen flamme der Leidenschaft
(13 jährige dürfen jetzt lachen)
oder doch eher nur heiße Luft.

Story zusammengefasst ohne namen:

Mädchen hat keine zauber Kräfte alle anderen haben sie das wird alls die schlimmste geistige krankheit angesehen und sie kommt in ein Irrenhaus.
Mädchen wird gemobbt und sucht nach liebe und gefühl und ist hoffnunglsoß
Die hausbesitzter werden verdächtigt Mana potion zu schmuggeln oder zu produzieren
3 leute 1. davon sehr relevant wird nach und nach zur Vaterfigur
noch etwas schneller alles wird immer komischer und niemand weis genau wer ehrlich ist und wer ein falsches Spiel
treibt oder das richtige tut. Dabei ist es aber zu keinem Zeitpunkt verwirrend.
Was Prositiv gesagt werden muss ist das öffters über die geistigen krankehiten 
philosophiert und departiert geworden istm, ohne am ende ein perfektes ergebnis zu gehabt zu haben.
Es sind Meinung und Einstellungen manchmal verschiedene Blick winkel aber nie perfekte Lösungen
was diesem Spiel sehr prositiv beinflusst hat.

tl.dr gut geschriebene Story mit Message 

Grafik und Style: Wenn man dem Spiel ein Zeitalter geben müsste wäre es warscheinlich das späte 19 oder die Anfänge des 20 Jahrunderts wobei ich mir dabei nicht sicher bin. Der Zeichenstyle ist Schwunghaft und spielerisch ein bischen Aquarell mäsig. Alle Charaktere sind schön Designed und sind teilweise einfach nur zum knuddeln oder verlieben je nachdem was ihr lieber habt. Negativ kann ich nur sagen das manche bilder extrem oft vorgekommen sind wie bei den Magiattacken.  Wobei als prositiv die Kampf koreograpien (wovon es leider nur sehr wenige gab) hervorzuhenen ist  puh ich schreib mich um kopf und Kragen reden wir doch jetz über 


Schreibstyle:

Schreibstyle und tempo: die Geschichte fließt Mäsig voran nicht zu schnell aber auch nicht zu langsam (wetter vorhersage diesen abend) nur 1 mal hatte ich das gefühl das es doch ein wenig schneller voran gehen soll und das war als ich aufs klo musste^_-.
Mann nimmt im Spiel verschiedene Personenperspektiven ein, von der Protaconistin über den Erzähler bis Aussenstehenden plotrelevanten Charakteren war alles dabei. Manchmal etwas verwirrend da es so kommt als würde ein Charakter für dich reden nur um dann plötzlich zu merken das du jemand anders Representierst. Es ist aber nie wirklichlich zu schlimm, solange man ordentlich liest und beim Plot am ball bleibt. Aber ich kann Verstehen falls jemand 1 stunde täglich dieses spiel spielt und dann die Story in 5 Tagen durch hat das er sich erstmal wieder rein finden muss um nicht verloren zu gehen

Die Kampfzehnen waren immer Detaltiert und sauber geschrieben. Dazu gab es auch eine Abwechslung beim Schreibstyle  das der Move erst in Bildern gezeigt wird und dann der Aufbau der Technick erklärt wird neben den normalen Kampfschreibstyle.

Musik: Sehr schön und passend. Viel Klavier und klassische Musik. Viele charaktere hatten ihre eigene kleine Melodie Die sehr gut auf die charaktere gepasst haben. ich würde aber persönlich nicht die CD kaufen maximal 1-2 Lieder als Errinnerung für meine Bibliotek. Die Soundeffekte waren mittelmäsig aber inordnung.

Fazit: 

Das Spiel hat einen sehr guten Eindruck auf mich hinterlassen.
Es war eine gute story mit einem nicht einfachen Thema was aber super umgesetzt wurde ohne dabei
den humor zu verlieren (und keine Sorge ihr werdet auch andere Gefühle noch bekommen). Es ist vom Technischen nicht perfekt und man merkt das es manchmal am Geld gefehlt hat.
Denoch war es für den 8 euro eine Erfahrung die Ich jedem wirklich empfehlen kann vorallem die jüngere generation
von 10-16 kann ich es empfehlen da es vieleicht Ihnen ein anderen Blickwinkel auf Klassenkameraden geben könnte
oder vieleicht ihnen zeigt das egal wie viele Schläge man einsteckt (philosophisch hoffentlich) und die Hoffnung schon aufgegeben hat, sich nicht selbstaufgeben kann den manchmal reicht ein lächerliches versprechen das dich am ende zum Ziel führt.

One Smal Fire At A Time bekommt von mir das predicat klein aber oho ... natürlich die Flamme!!!!
